“Currently, we are coordinating with the shelters that are housing those who have lost their homes and assessing the long- and short-term health care needs, including the mental health needs, of the tens of thousands of people that have been injured.” Because of the earthquake devastation, health facilities and health access have been severely impacted, and some 15 hospitals have reportedly “buckled."

“We know that thousands of people are still under buildings and because more than 6,500 buildings collapsed, and lots of them were apartments between five and 15 floors,” said Gulcin Guresci, CEO of AKUT, a nonprofit volunteer rescue organization that is now focused on helping find people in damaged buildings.
